question: If you were to see people touching a bronze statue’s shoes, the building Sever Hall, and the color crimson, you would realize you were at what university hosting this Certamen competition?
What man, whose shoe people touch, is the mascot of Harvard?
This tournament’s opening meeting at Sever Hall featured a wonderful talk by what Professor? Moderator should say: “Subsequent questions will count for points. Good luck and have fun!”
What author, whose “maiden’s song” for Juno won honor for the collēgium scrībārum histriōnumque, wrote plays like Ajax Mastigophorus and a Saturnian-meter translation of Homer’s Odyssey?
Give the Latin term for Livius’ position in Rome as a teacher of Latin and Greek.
In whose entourage was Livius brought to Rome following the end of the war between Rome and Tarentum in 272 B.C.?
Who recounted how he hid among seals with his men to capture Proteus, the sea god who told him about the fates of the other Greek leaders and how he could safely return to Sparta?
What daughter of Proteus helped Menelaus capture him?
Proteus lived on Pharos, an island off the coast of what modern day country?
A future participle agreeing with the subject, a relative clause after a verb like mittō, an accusative gerundive with ad, and a simple ut clause are all ways to express what concept in Latin?
Using a relative clause of purpose, say in Latin “He sent an ambassador to look at the enemies’ camp.”
answer: LĒGĀTUM MĪSIT QUĪ HOSTIUM CASTRA SPECTĀRET

question: Now translate this sentence adapted from Livy, which uses a surprising tense for an ut purpose clause: “Dictātor, nē frūstrā creātus esset, in pāce aliquid facere cupiēbat.”
At what Thracian city, named after the husband of Vibia Sabina, did a group of dispossessed Goths in the late 4th century win a deadly battle against the emperor Valens?
What emperor defeated Maximinus Daza, sometimes called Daia, at Adrianople in 313 A.D., only to lose to Constantine there about a decade later?
The Goths had initially fled from their homes due to the raids of what tribe?
What Latin word, in various forms, fills in the blanks in these phrases: “caelī ēnārrant [blank] Deī”; “ad maiōrem Deī [blank]”; “sīc trānsit [blank] mundī.”
What Catholic religious order has the motto “ad maiōrem Deī glōriam”?
Give the four-word Latin name of the hymn whose name means “glory to God in the highest.”
Caesar’s phrase “cīvitās maximam habet opīniōnem virtūtis” — along with “vacātiō labōrum,” “dēsīderium ōtiī,” and “amor pācis” — shows what genitive use often contrasted with subjective?
What use of the genitive is found in the phrases “ubinam gentium sumus?” and “parum ōtī”?
What use of the genitive is found in Horace’s lines “magnī formīca labōris ōre trahit quodcumque potest”?
What city, whose rivers Asterion, Cephissus, and Inachus were periodically dry for not choosing Poseidon over Hera as the patron, sent champions against Thebes and had kings including Perseus?
What famous Argive city did Perseus found after trading Argos for Tiryns?
What descendant of Io, fleeing his brother, came from Egypt to claim his right to the Argive throne?
A foundation of stones called the statūmen and a nine-inch layer of concrete called the rūdus were both used to make what sort of object, examples of which include the Aemilia and Salāria?
What was the final layer of the road, which was a six-inch bedding of fine concrete?
What curbstones were used to set bounds on the road on both sides?

What author destroyed his signet ring and removed Nero from his will before his suicide, though he had been the emperor’s arbiter elegantiae and used his experience with debauchery to write the Satyricōn?
Who is the protagonist of the Satyricōn, traveling with Ascyltos and Giton?
The devolution of the relationship between Petronius and Nero took place over only a few years. In what year had Nero elevated Petronius to the consulship?
What conflict saw brothers nicknamed the “Thunderbolts of War” die near the Baetis River in the same year that the so-called “Sword of War” recaptured Syracuse — 211 B.C.?
What battle did these “Thunderbolts of War” — the Scipio brothers — win in Spain a year after the Battle of Cannae?
In what year did Fabius Maximus Cunctator, the so-called “Shield of War,” recapture Tarentum?
What people, who later lost a battle at Silva Malitiōsa, attended a festival of Neptune or Consus in a newly-founded city, enabling their Roman hosts to seize their women for themselves?
What was the capital city of the Sabines, the birthplace of Romulus’s successor?
What Sabine chief managed to seize the Capitoline citadel in 460 B.C., though he was quickly dislodged by Gaius Claudius and Publius Valerius?
What Latin verb, with what meaning, is at the root of a word describing a pause in the middle of a poetic foot, as well as the words “scissors,” “cement,” and “precision”?
What derivative of caedō is a tool used for carving material such as wood?

The pause in the middle of a foot is a caesura. In hexameter poetry, a pause between the fourth and fifth feet is a “bucolic diaeresis.” From what Latin words with what meanings is “bucolic” derived? BŌS – COW and COLŌ – CULTIVATE
Of the words testis, virga, pollex, vīmen, and pollen, which is being described here? Index est quī crīmina aliōrum in iūdiciō dēmōnstrat.
Of the words latex, virga, pollex, vīmen, and pollen, which two are most closely synonymous? VIRGA and VĪMEN
Of the words latex, pollex, discrīmen, and pollen, which is most synonymous with perīculum?
Either by pretending to be a priestess of Hyperborean Artemis, or by rejuvenating her father-in-law Aeson, what woman’s trickery caused Pelias to die and Jason to become king of Iolcus?
In some sources, Aeson is forced to kill himself by drinking the poisonous blood of what animal?
Medea, out of jealousy, murdered what daughter of Creon after Jason said he would marry her?

What poet, central to the pagans’ talks in Macrobius’s Sāturnālia, accidentally appealed to Christians by showing a child ushering in a golden age in the 4th poem, known as “Messianic,” of his Eclogues?
Vergil was born near what town, whose status as a victim of Augustus’s land confiscations is alluded to in the Eclogues?
What poet makes an appearance in Poem 10 of the Eclogues, which puts the pastoral landscape in dialogue with the world of elegy?
In Ovid’s Metamorphoses, the story of what river-goddess is told within the tale of Persephone, since she saw the Underworld during her flight from Greece to Sicily to escape the clutches of Alpheus?
Arethusa’s story in the Metamorphoses is the culmination of a large series of nested narratives, since the story of Persephone is in turn narrated by the Muses during their contest with what mortals?
Continuing this story-ception, the contest with the Pierides is narrated to Minerva by one of the Muses shortly after escaping the clutches of what evil Thracian king, who tried to rape them?

Like Galba, what aged emperor gave the Praetorians only low pay and harsh discipline when Laetus and Eclectus raised him to power, kicking off an auction for the throne and a Year of the Five Emperors?
What woman had worked alongside Laetus and Eclectus to kill Commodus?
What rogue Praetorian Prefect had promised the soldiers that Galba would give them a donative, making it all the more disappointing when he refused?
What genre, whose first Roman practitioners actually wrote in Greek, was pioneered in Latin prose with a seven-book work by Cato the Elder and arguably reached its peak with Tacitus’s Annālēs?
What work by Tacitus is his only non-historical work and is structured as a Ciceronian dialogue?
What author, who got his name because one of his ancestors had been a painter, was the first Roman to write history?
Please translate this sentence from Latin into English: “Vergilius tam aeger est ut nōn possit librum perficere.”
answer: VERGIL IS SO ILL THAT HE CANNOT COMPLETE THE BOOK

question: Now translate this sentence from Latin into English: “Lēgāmus opus Ovidiī in quō loquitur dē mūtātīs fōrmīs.”
Now translate this sentence from Latin into English: “Cum Nerōnem laudāvisset, Lūcānus tamen coniūrātiōnis particeps esse cōnstituit.”
What one-syllable Latin conjunction, which is sometimes joined with modo in a proviso clause, surprisingly always takes the present indicative when it has the meaning “while”?
What tense and mood would follow dum if it translated “for” in the sentence “The soldier was waiting for his commander to arrive”?

When dum is followed by a past tense indicative, as in Vergil’s line “dulcēs exuviae, dum fāta deusque sinēbat,” it can loosely be translated as “while,” but what is the more precise sense? You can either give a different translation or explain verbally how it differs from dum with the present.

Listen carefully to the following passage about the First Punic War, which I will read twice, then answer in Latin the question that follows. Cum Poenī cōnsulem prohibērent in Siciliam trānsīre, is sparsit rūmōrem, quasi sibi bellum gerere nōn iam licēret, et classem retrō ēgit. Dīgressīs deinde Poenīs, quī profectiōnī ēius crēdiderant, nāvēs Siciliae appulit. The question: Quī crēdulī erant et dīgressī sunt?
Cūr cōnsul in Siciliam transīre nōn poterat?
Quid in rūmōre dictum est?
answer: CŌNSULĪ BELLUM GERERE NŌN IAM {LICĒRE / LICET}

question: Lines consisting entirely of spondees and a line addressing Titus Tatius in excessive alliteration show what author’s willingness to experiment with the brand-new dactylic hexameter in his Annālēs?
What sound did Ennius express with the onomatopoeia “taratantara”?
Name either of the two comedies by Ennius, one about a wrestler and another about an innkeeper’s wife. CAUPUNCULA or PANCRATIASTĒS
How many words in the following English sentence are derived from Latin? “While avidly watching birds outside the national convention, I saw several ospreys.”
Provide the ultimate Latin root of two English words from the above sentence. For words formed from more than one Latin root, you only need to provide one.
Provide the rest.
Who installed reflective marble in his palace shortly after Lappius Maximus barely ended the revolt of Saturninus, though this did not save him from a stab in the groin by his butler Stephanus?
What famous generalissimo was the father of Domitian’s wife?
Saturninus had tried to induce what German tribe to rebel and invade Roman borders?
What woman remained with her father until he passed at Colonus, before returning to her home where she tried to bury her cursed brother Polynices in defiance of the decree of Creon?
What fiancé of Antigone, a son of Creon, committed suicide upon learning of her death?
Colonus was a suburb of what city, whose king secured the burial of the Seven Against Thebes?
The Halieutica is a minor work of what author, who gave voice to Briseis and other women, addressed Corinna in his Amōrēs, and wrote a 15-book epic poem called Metamorphōsēs?
After being banished by Augustus, Ovid spent the last years of his life in what city, where he composed his Tristia and Epistulae ex Pontō?
What minor work of Ovid, named after a bird, wishes several hundred terrible mythological punishments on an unnamed enemy?

Which two states are the only ones with one-word Latin mottos, one of which is a first-person verb meaning “I direct” and the other of which is a comparative adjective meaning “higher”? MAINE and NEW YORK
There are three states with a four-word Latin motto. Identify one of them and give the motto.
answer: ASPERA // VERMONT – STĒLLA QUĀRTA DECIMA FULGEAT

question: There are two states with a six-word Latin motto. Identify one of them and give the motto.
answer: MASSACHUSETTS – ĒNSE PETIT PLACIDAM SUB LĪBERTĀTE QUIĒTEM

question: According to Polybius, famous paintings were used as gaming tables after what city, which raised Critolaus as its dictator, was sacked by Lucius Mummius in 146 B.C.?
Which Roman general, fresh off victories against Andriscus in 148 B.C., left Macedonia in order to deal with Critolaus?
According to Livy, what Corinthian noble fled to Italy early in Rome’s history, and had a son whose name reflected the Etruscan city he settled in?
Nereus alone knew how to find what wedding gift of Gaea, a place defended by the serpent Ladon, tended to by a few sisters, and breached by either Atlas or Heracles during a labor?
Sometimes the location of the Hesperides was near what tribe that lived in the far, far north?
On his way to the Hesperides, Heracles had killed what king of Egypt who tried sacrificing him, alongside other strangers, to Zeus?
What city acted as the eastern terminus of the via Egnātia, was split into two by a strait called “Bosporus,” and was the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire before it was renamed “Istanbul”?
Give the ancient name for the body of water that bordered Constantinople to the north.
Give the ancient name for the Sea of Marmara, which bordered Constantinople to the south.
Exiled for killing his half-brother Phocus, who went to Phthia, where he became king, welcomed men like Phoenix and Patroclus, and let them accompany his son by Thetis, Achilles?

After moving to Phthia, Peleus had to get purified again for killing his father-in-law, and sought out what king of Iolcus, who had previously been an Argonaut alongside Peleus in defiance of his father?
Give the reasons for why either Phoenix or Patroclus came to Phthia. or PATROCLUS HAD KILLED A BOY (CLITONYMUS OVER A DICE GAME)
answer: PHOENIX HAD SLEPT WITH HIS FATHER’S CONCUBINE AND GOT IN TROUBLE

question: According to a Roman poet, the existence of what objects removes any fear of death, accounts for free will through clīnāmen, forms the core of Epicureanism, and explains the rērum nātūra scientifically?
In Lucretius’s work, what deity personifies Nature’s generative force and the Epicurean ideal of ataraxy, or undisturbedness?

Say in Latin: “If I had come home, I would have seen you.” For this sentence, both verbs should be pluperfect subjunctive.
Now say in Latin: “Would I see you tomorrow if I were to come again?”
answer: VIDEAMNE TĒ CRAS SĪ ITERUM VENIAM?

question: Finally, say in Latin: “If only I were able to run for ten hours to see you!”
answer: UTINAM POSSEM DECEM HORĀS CURRERE {UT TĒ VIDĒREM // AD TĒ VIDENDUM}

question: Members of what people swore an oath in a linen-covered tent before joining battle at Aquilonia in 293 B.C., the last battle of a three-war conflict that also saw a defeat at Caudine Forks?

Hecate’s appearance on earth was often accompanied by what animals — which the queen Hecuba transformed into — though the most famous examples of these beasts were Orthrus and Cerberus?

Translate into idiomatic Latin without using nōn or any such adverb: “Alexander’s soldiers said that they would not follow him.” [pause] To do this, you should use a verb for “denied.”
answer: MĪLITĒS ALEXANDRĪ NEGĀVĒRUNT SĒ EUM SECŪTŪROS (ESSE)

question: Now translate into good Latin: “Alexander said that the soldiers who were remaining would receive rewards.”
answer: ALEXANDER DĪXIT (EŌS) MĪLITĒS QUĪ (RĒ)MĀNĒRENT PRAEMIA ACCEPTŪRŌS (ESSE)

question: Now translate: “Hannibal thought that he ought to be praised a little less than Alexander and Pyrrhus.”

answer: THE DANAIDS MURDERING THEIR HUSBANDS (ON THEIR WEDDING NIGHT)

question: Pallas had originally planned to fight what son of Mezentius?

answer: HE WAS A FREED SLAVE // HE WAS FROM CARTHAGE AND HAD TO LEARN LATIN

question: According to legend, Terence had to present his first comedy for approval to what other comic playwright, the author of Plocium?

What is the more standard past participle of tueor?

From what author do we get the quotes “pulvis et umbra sumus,” “sapere audē” “aurea mediocritās,” and “dulce et decōrum est prō patriā morī”?

answer: AGŌ [PROMPT ON “CŌGŌ” BEFORE IT IS READ]

question: What Latin word is at the ultimate root of “squad,” as well as “square”?
From what Latin verb with what meaning do we get “squash?” The “s” comes from the prefix ex-, which intensifies this verb.
Translate the following sentence into alliterative Latin using a passive periphrastic: “Sextus must follow the seven allies.”
Translate the following sentence into alliterative Latin using a gerund: “We will be able to gain the reward by fighting.”

answer: {CUPĪDŌ / CUPIDITĀS} CELERITER CORINTHUM CURRENDĪ CRASSUM CĒPIT

question: What figure in Latin literature, who “first captured” a “wretched” poet with her ocellī, may have had the real name Hostia and was the chief subject of the Monobiblos by Propertius?

The words “Ollus Quiris lētō datus…” preceded what sort of event, which featured a special lectus, actors wearing imāginēs, a dēsignātor who organized it, and a laudātiō fūnebris?
Give the Latin word for the act performed when a Roman died at home, where the eldest son bent over the body and called the father by name.
What was the aptly named sort of funeral performed for very young children?

Whom did Nero marry — though not for long — after divorcing Octavia, taking her from her previous husband?

Name Augustine’s mother.

For the verb adimō, give the 3rd person plural, perfect passive subjunctive, keeping in mind that it is a compound of emō and forms its fourth principal part with the same vowel as emō.
Give the same form for attingō.
Make both the form from the tossup and first bonus active. ADĒMERINT and ATTIGERINT
Because her son looked too much like his Thracian father, what Athenian princess murdered her son Itys before serving him to Tereus to get revenge for her sister Philomela?

Dēscrībāmus nunc proprietātēs dictiōnum in hāc sententia: “dīs genite et genitūre deōs.” Quō cāsū sunt et “genite” et “genitūre”?
What use of the ablative is exemplified by the word dīs?
What modern English letter is orthographically descended from the Greek letter which gives its name to the rhetorical device in that quote?
What author, who cites his father’s participation at Bedriacum for an anecdote, goes per speciēs in a gossipy and rumor-heavy style through the lives and personalities of twelve Roman rulers?
Under what emperor was Suetonius employed in the imperial archives, giving him a wealth of material with which to compose his biographies?

What name is shared by a senator whose support of the lēx Sempronia Agrāria got him a spot on the Gracchi’s land commission, and the co-consul of Junius Pullus who failed to heed the chickens?
Tiberius Gracchus came to prominence while on the staff of Gaius Hostilius Mancinus during the siege of what city, which was finally defeated in the year of his tribunate?

Translate the following exclamation into English: “Quam pulcher est homō quī virtūtem habet!”
answer: HOW BEAUTIFUL IS A MAN WHO HAS VIRTUE!

question: Translate the following sentence into English: “Quotiēns mūlus aquam bibit, totiēns ego vīnum.”
answer: AS OFTEN AS A MULE DRINKS WATER I DO (DRINK) WINE

question: Finally, translate this one: “Tantō mē pauperior eris quantō tē sapientior sum.”
answer: YOU WILL BE AS MUCH POORER THAN I AS I AM WISER THAN YOU

question: What king, who lived with his 6 sons and 6 daughters that were married to one another, refused to help Odysseus when he returned 10 days later after his crew had opened the bag of winds?

Works in what form were famously discovered by Petrarch after being posthumously published by Tiro, revealing their author’s relations with Lucceius and other familiārēs as well as his best friend Atticus?
What author’s disappointingly mediocre letter-collection, which includes a reference to a historical work on the Parthian wars of Lucius Verus, was rediscovered in the 19th century?

Identify and correct the mistake, if any, in the following Latin sentence: Līberōs meōs īrātus rogāvī quō pridiē īverint et quid fēcissent.
Identify and correct the mistake, if any, in the following Latin sentence: Adeō magistrum timeō nē eum alloquī audeam.
Identify and correct the mistake, if any, in the following Latin sentence, which is intended to have a purpose clause: Fugiō ut nēmō mē inveniat.
answer: UT NĒMŌ SHOULD BE NĒ QUIS

question: The capture of Vetera was the high point of whose revolt, which was incited by Fonteius Capito’s false accusations and saw him pretend to support Vespasian before Cerealis defeated his Batavian forces?

Cerealis also fought in Britain and seems to have dealt with a revolt by Venutius, the former husband of what Brigantian queen who once turned Caratacus over to the Romans?

What island, which saw a sacrifice to Apollo, Artemis, and Leto after the murder of Thersites, was the birthplace of the pirate-fleeing, dolphin-riding Greek singer Arion, and the home of Orpheus’s lyre?
Why did Achilles murder Thersites?
answer: FOR MOCKING HIM FOR LAMENTING AFTER MURDERING PENTHESILEA

question: Arion had spent most of his life at the court of what tyrant of Corinth?
What type of object are all of the following: phasēlus, scapha, ratis, and — by metonymy — puppis?
Navēs onerāriae taedā et pice et stuppā complētae sunt. Quid Anglicē significat “pix”?
Navis in syrtim incessit. Quid Anglicē significat “syrtis”?

When Heracles was wounded and fell to his knees while battling the Ligurians, what miraculous event did Zeus send to save him, which explains the terrain around the city of Marseilles?

What author’s “Tale of the Tub” was potentially inspired by Aristides and the fābulae Milēsiae, which he combines with knowledge about the cults of Osiris and Isis in an 11-book narrative about Lucius?
What Republican historian, a so-called ēmendātor sermōnis ūsitātī, penned a Latin collection of fābulae Milēsiae?

What law of 55 B.C. was one such deal, as it procured governorships in Syria and Spain for Crassus and Pompey, respectively?
